channel.title: How to write a Essay & get an A!
channel.description:
Okay first of all. The problem with most essays is that the content is disorganized. You may have great ideas and facts that you want to write about, but somewhere during the writing process you start mixing them up. Suddenly your perfect paper sounds all wrong and you want to scream!
What you need to do is have a good solid outline. Once you have an outline down, your paper writes itself. Your thoughts are organized and the teacher can understand your main point (which is your thesis) and how you supported that thesis. You need to be focused, and that is the key to writing a good essay.
This is a good outline format that they teach in school. I have been following this format and have had 98-100%'s on my essays.
I. Topic / Title
II. Introduction of Essay A. Grab the reader's attention. Then write a few sentences (2 or 3) that lead into the main point of your essay B. End the paragraph with your thesis statement (3 main points you are going to support) 1. First point in thesis 2. Second point in thesis 3. Third point in thesis
III. Body of Essay A. First Paragraph - First point in Thesis 1. Support your point with either quotations or solid evidence 2. Have at least five sentences B. Second Paragraph - Second point in Thesis 1. Support your point with either quotations or solid evidence 2. Have at least five sentences C. Third Paragraph - Third Point in Thesis 1. Support your point with either quotations or solid evidence 2. Have at least five sentences
IV. Conclusion A. Write a few sentences summarizing your essay B. Restate your thesis and how you proved your point
Here are some other pointers.
Don't have run on sentences. Use commas and semicolons.
Don't use the same words again and again.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Some more help.
1. Miscellaneous observations on a topic are not enough to make an accomplished academic essay. An essay should have an argument. It should answer a question or a few related questions (see 2 below). It should try to prove something--develop a single "thesis" or a short set of closely related points--by reasoning and evidence, especially including apt examples and confirming citations from any particular text or sources your argument involves. Gathering such evidence normally entails some rereading of the text or sources with a question or provisional thesis in mind.
2. When--as is usually the case--an assigned topic does not provide you with a thesis ready-made, your first effort should be to formulate as exactly as possible the question(s) you will seek to answer in your essay. Next, develop by thinking, reading, and jotting a provisional thesis or hypothesis. Don't become prematurely committed to this first answer. Pursue it, but test it--even to the point of consciously asking yourself what might be said against it--and be ready to revise or qualify it as your work progresses. (Sometimes a suggestive possible title one discovers early can serve in the same way.)
3. There are many ways in which any particular argument may be well presented, but an essay's organization--how it begins, develops, and ends--should be designed to present your argument clearly and persuasively. (The order in which you discovered the parts of your argument is seldom an effective order for presenting it to a reader.)
4. Successful methods of composing an essay are various, but some practices of good writers are almost invariable:
* They start writing early, even before they think they are "ready" to write, because they use writing not simply to transcribe what they have already discovered but as a means of exploration and discovery. * They don't try to write an essay from beginning to end, but rather write what seems readiest to be written, even if they're not sure whether or how it will fit in. * Despite writing so freely, they keep the essay's overall purpose and organization in mind, amending them as drafting proceeds. Something like an "outline" constantly and consciously evolves, although it may never take any written form beyond scattered, sketchy reminders to oneself. * They revise extensively. Rather than writing a single draft and then merely editing its sentences one by one, they attend to the whole essay and draft and redraft--rearranging the sequence of its larger parts, adding and deleting sections to take account of what they discover in the course of composition. Such revision often involves putting the essay aside for a few days, allowing the mind to work indirectly or subconsciously in the meantime and making it possible to see the work-in-progress more objectively when they return to it. * Once they have a fairly complete and well-organized draft, they revise sentences, with special attention to transitions--that is, checking to be sure that a reader will be able to follow the sequences of ideas within sentences, from sentence to sentence, and from paragraph to paragraph. Two other important considerations in revising sentences are diction (exactness and aptness of words) and economy (the fewest words without loss of clear expression and full thought). Lastly, they proofread the final copy.
----------------------------------Following posted by Ron-------------------------------- Don't start sentences using the word But, or Because.
Don't use slang. (I failed an essay once in 7th grade when I did this.)
Use descriptive words. You probably don't read and have a poor vocabulary. That is very bad. You need to read and improve on that. No more... "The fat guy fell into the pool" type of setences. Use setences like "The obese foolish man was not being cautious since he was so drunk, he lost his balance and fell right into the pool."
Here are some more Do's and Don'ts. http://www.accepted.com/grad/personalstatement.aspx
Hope this helps.

item.title: How to write a Essay & get an A!
item.dc:creator: @leader leader
item.description:
@leader wrote:

xxlegitxx:

no, it should be “an essay”. hes rite.

Yes, I know. I wasn’t thinking when I replied back. I am too stressed out so I am not thinking properly; I’ve been doing homework everyday until 11 or 12. I’m just too tired, and can’t be bothered.

Sorry mate.

-Leader

item.description:
@leader wrote:

It is not supposed to be “an” because I added “& get an A” so it is correct as it.

item.source: How to write a Essay & get an A!

item.title: How to write a Essay & get an A!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

leader:

Your not supposed to. It isn’t correct.

Yeah a lot of teachers take off points. Better be safe, than sorry.

Explain what you’re defending when you are saying because. Don’t just say…

Because the girl was so hot, I couldn’t do anything to stop myself (but why would I any way lol?).

Say instead…

I was out late becayse the girl was so hot… etc

I got points off for starting sentences with Because and most teachers would do the same.

~Ron

Read full topic
item.source: How to write a Essay & get an A!

item.title: How to write a Essay & get an A!
item.dc:creator: @KyleGut3 KyleGut3
item.description:
@KyleGut3 wrote:

… you can start a sentence with because… though you have to make sure it isnt a Fragment. i.e

fragment:

Because I could.

Complete:

Because I murdered my English teacher, I was sent to jail.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Nah. Your method is probably better for most purposes. I just use my method for when I get bored of writing essays.

item.source: How to write a Essay & get an A!

item.title: How to write a Essay & get an A!
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

This is what I learned to write an awesome persuasive essay.

I. Intro
A. Brief Background
B. Thesis
II. History (while introducing key terms)
A. Major Fact
B. Major Fact
C. Major Fact
III.My Viewpoint
A. Restate Thesis
B. Supporting Facts
C. Supporting Facts
D. Etc.
IV.Conclusion
A. Benefits to society
B. Discuss counter-argument, and dispell doubt.
C. Make concessions (acknowledge holes in your argument)

Realize that each roman numeral can represent multiple paragraphs. Don’t use this unless you’re absolutely sure your teacher wont mind the unconventional layout. If you guys want, I can post a killer essay I wrote with this format.

[quote=“Ron, post:5, topic:10587”]Of course not.

Hey what’s up with some of your sentences? They look like this.

â€¢ Donâ€™t have run on sentences. Use commas and semicolons.

â€¢ Donâ€™t use the same words again and again.

lol. Weird.[/quote]

Go to View --> Character Encoding --> Unicode (UTF-8)

Read full topic

@leader wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:5, topic:10587”]Of course not.

Hey what’s up with some of your sentences? They look like this.

â€¢ Donâ€™t have run on sentences. Use commas and semicolons.

lol. Weird.[/quote]

I don’t know why it became like that, but I fixed it.[br][size=1]Posted at: August 25, 2006, 09:21:18 PM[/size][hr][quote=“mindtempest, post:6, topic:10587”]i get that too, prolly an encoding error since im using portable firefox atm. my ff at home doesnt have that problem.[/quote]

It looks weird with internet explorer too.[br][size=1]Posted at: August 25, 2006, 08:28:17 PM[/size][hr]I am writing an application for a Science and Engineering program at my school and it is due tomorrow. It prepares and exposes the academically talented students to careers in the Science and Engineering fields. Anyone know any strong vocab words that are good to use?

item.title: How to write a Essay & get an A!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

I hate Essays…

For the last 2 and a half months, I couldn’t even find a pencil lol. Oh and you forgot…

Don’t start sentences using the word But.

Don’t use slang. (I failed an essay once in 7th grade when I did this.)

Use descriptive words. You probably don’t read and have a poor vocabulary. That is very bad. You need to read and improve on that. No more… “The fat guy fell into the pool” type of setences. Use setences like “The obese foolish man was not being cautious since he was so drunk, he lost his balance and fell right into the pool.”

Here are some more Do’s and Don’ts.

accepted.com

Graduate School Admissions Essay Writing

Create a captivating, thoughtful, and well-written grad school personal statement or statement of purpose. Check out Grad School Essay Writing 101.

~Ron

Read full topic

item.title: How to write a Essay & get an A!
item.dc:creator: @leader leader
item.description:
@leader wrote:

Okay first of all. The problem with most essays is that the content is disorganized. You may have great ideas and facts that you want to write about, but somewhere during the writing process you start mixing them up. Suddenly your perfect paper sounds all wrong and you want to scream!

What you need to do is have a good solid outline. Once you have an outline down, your paper writes itself. Your thoughts are organized and the teacher can understand your main point (which is your thesis) and how you supported that thesis. You need to be focused, and that is the key to writing a good essay.

This is a good outline format that they teach in school. I have been following this format and have had 98-100%'s on my essays.

I. Topic / Title

II. Introduction of Essay
A. Grab the reader’s attention. Then write a few sentences (2 or 3) that lead into the main point of your essay
B. End the paragraph with your thesis statement (3 main points you are going to support)
1. First point in thesis
2. Second point in thesis
3. Third point in thesis

III. Body of Essay
A. First Paragraph - First point in Thesis
1. Support your point with either quotations or solid evidence
2. Have at least five sentences
B. Second Paragraph - Second point in Thesis
1. Support your point with either quotations or solid evidence
2. Have at least five sentences
C. Third Paragraph - Third Point in Thesis
1. Support your point with either quotations or solid evidence
2. Have at least five sentences

IV. Conclusion
A. Write a few sentences summarizing your essay
B. Restate your thesis and how you proved your point

Here are some other pointers.

Don’t have run on sentences. Use commas and semicolons.

Don’t use the same words again and again.

Some more help.

  1. Miscellaneous observations on a topic are not enough to make an accomplished academic essay. An essay should have an argument. It should answer a question or a few related questions (see 2 below). It should try to prove something–develop a single “thesis” or a short set of closely related points–by reasoning and evidence, especially including apt examples and confirming citations from any particular text or sources your argument involves. Gathering such evidence normally entails some rereading of the text or sources with a question or provisional thesis in mind.

  2. When–as is usually the case–an assigned topic does not provide you with a thesis ready-made, your first effort should be to formulate as exactly as possible the question(s) you will seek to answer in your essay. Next, develop by thinking, reading, and jotting a provisional thesis or hypothesis. Don’t become prematurely committed to this first answer. Pursue it, but test it–even to the point of consciously asking yourself what might be said against it–and be ready to revise or qualify it as your work progresses. (Sometimes a suggestive possible title one discovers early can serve in the same way.)

  3. There are many ways in which any particular argument may be well presented, but an essay’s organization–how it begins, develops, and ends–should be designed to present your argument clearly and persuasively. (The order in which you discovered the parts of your argument is seldom an effective order for presenting it to a reader.)

  4. Successful methods of composing an essay are various, but some practices of good writers are almost invariable:

  • They start writing early, even before they think they are “ready” to write, because they use writing not simply to transcribe what they have already discovered but as a means of exploration and discovery.
  • They don’t try to write an essay from beginning to end, but rather write what seems readiest to be written, even if they’re not sure whether or how it will fit in.
  • Despite writing so freely, they keep the essay’s overall purpose and organization in mind, amending them as drafting proceeds. Something like an “outline” constantly and consciously evolves, although it may never take any written form beyond scattered, sketchy reminders to oneself.
  • They revise extensively. Rather than writing a single draft and then merely editing its sentences one by one, they attend to the whole essay and draft and redraft–rearranging the sequence of its larger parts, adding and deleting sections to take account of what they discover in the course of composition. Such revision often involves putting the essay aside for a few days, allowing the mind to work indirectly or subconsciously in the meantime and making it possible to see the work-in-progress more objectively when they return to it.
  • Once they have a fairly complete and well-organized draft, they revise sentences, with special attention to transitions–that is, checking to be sure that a reader will be able to follow the sequences of ideas within sentences, from sentence to sentence, and from paragraph to paragraph. Two other important considerations in revising sentences are diction (exactness and aptness of words) and economy (the fewest words without loss of clear expression and full thought). Lastly, they proofread the final copy.

----------------------------------Following posted by Ron--------------------------------
Don’t start sentences using the word But, or Because.

Don’t use slang. (I failed an essay once in 7th grade when I did this.)

Use descriptive words. You probably don’t read and have a poor vocabulary. That is very bad. You need to read and improve on that. No more… “The fat guy fell into the pool” type of setences. Use setences like “The obese foolish man was not being cautious since he was so drunk, he lost his balance and fell right into the pool.”

Here are some more Do’s and Don’ts.

accepted.com

Graduate School Admissions Essay Writing

Create a captivating, thoughtful, and well-written grad school personal statement or statement of purpose. Check out Grad School Essay Writing 101.

Hope this helps.
